engagementHook.title: The Invisible Current
engagementHook.content: You drop sugar into your tea. You don't stir, yet five minutes later, every sip is sweet. No energy expended, no proteins involved—just physics. Your cells perform this same trick 2 trillion times per second.

contentSections.title: Simple Diffusion
contentSections.content:
Simple diffusion is the net movement of particles from an area of high concentration to low concentration. This is passive—it requires no metabolic energy (ATP).

Key Principle: The cell doesn't 'do' anything; the laws of thermodynamics drive the movement.

Biological Example: Oxygen diffuses from lungs (high O₂) into blood (lower O₂). Carbon dioxide diffuses out. Both follow their concentration gradients.

contentSections.title: Facilitated Diffusion
contentSections.content:
Large or charged molecules cannot pass through the hydrophobic core. They require facilitated diffusion—still passive (no ATP), but using membrane proteins as tunnels or ferries.

Channel Proteins

  • Form pores through membrane
  • Allow continuous flow
  • Example: Aquaporins (water channels)

Carrier Proteins

  • Have binding sites
  • Undergo shape change
  • Example: Glucose transporters

contentSections.title: Factors Affecting Diffusion Rate
contentSections.content:
Several factors affect how quickly substances diffuse across membranes:

  1. Concentration Gradient: Steeper gradient = faster rate. As equilibrium approaches, rate slows.
  2. Temperature: Higher temp = more kinetic energy = faster diffusion.
  3. Surface Area: More membrane area = more sites for entry.
  4. Membrane Thickness: Thinner membrane = shorter distance = faster diffusion.
